answers.answer: Hello slicedoranges,I am one of the volunteers here, so, do keep in mind that I am not a medical professional.  My advice / input is based on knowledge from personal experience with my son who is 10 and was diagnosed with type 1 at the age of 3.Today is my day to volunteer.  I am sorry you did not receive a response before today.  I am unsure why this happened.  We have great volunters here, so I apologize that your question somehow slipped through.I am guessing (but you can confirm this) that your mother had type 1 diabetes, especially since she was 15 when diagnosed.  (nowadays they are finding more kids / teens that are being diagnosed with type 2 when overweight)To be completely honest with you, I am unsure what your chances are in being diagnosed with type 1 because your mother has it.  My husband's father had type 1, yet my husband, and his brother and sister do not, BUT, our son does.  My sister was diagnosed with type 1 in early adulthood - at age 24.  (She is now 33.)  So, when it comes to my son, we had it on both sides of the family.Remember, I am NOT a doctor or medical professional, but, as I mentioned, nowadays they are seeing that children & teens who are overweight are at risk for type 2.slicedoranges, (by the way...cute name!)I am going to give you some links below for you to check out:http://lifewise.ahealthyadvantage.com/topic/type2kids(the one above tells about type 2 in kids / teens)www.diabetes.org(the site above is the American Diabetes Association - in the search box up in the right hand corner, type some keywords such as:type 2 in teens OR preventing type 2)Another page from the site above that might be helpful:http://www.diabetes.org/pre-diabetes/pre-diabetes-symptoms.jspI feel that you need to talk to your doctor about your concerns and possibly your doctor can perform some tests such as the ones described on the page above.  Also, it might be a good idea to see a nutritionist.  If you do not exercise, possibly start walking a few times a week.Please feel free to post again and PLEASE follow up with your doctor.  I understand your concern.  Express your concerns to your doc.This page explains risk factors for type 1:http://my.webmd.com/hw/diabetes_1_2/uq1456.aspTake care:)

question: My mom was diagnosed with diabetes when she was a year younger than I am now, and I'm 16 years old and weigh 250 (give or take)pounds. My BMI is 29. Is there any way of knowing my odds of obtaining type 1 diabetes?
title: What are my chances?
